title: 110_s3650
content: The Act is titled the "Salmon Lake Land Selection Resolution Act" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. Congress finds that Salmon Lake and its surrounding areas contain important fisheries and cultural resources significant to Alaska Natives and residents of the state. The land offers recreational opportunities and is suitable for various activities. The Alaska Statehood Act of 1958 has led to conflicting land selections in the Salmon Lake area by the Bering Straits Native Corporation and the State of Alaska. The Secretary of the Interior, State, and Corporation have agreed to protect and preserve the historical significance of the area. To protect and preserve the historical, cultural, and natural resources of the Salmon Lake area, resolve conflicting land selections made by the State and the Bering Straits Native Corporation under relevant Acts, and ensure continued public ownership and management. The text chunk discusses the conveyance of certain land in the Salmon Lake area to the State and the Bering Straits Native Corporation to resolve conflicting land selections and ensure public ownership and access. Legislation is required to ratify the Salmon Lake Area Land Ownership and Consolidation Agreement between the Secretary of the Interior, the State of Alaska, and the Bering Straits Native Corporation to resolve conflicting land selections. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Agreement" refers to the document titled "Salmon Lake Area Land Ownership and Consolidation Agreement" executed by the Secretary, the State, and the Bering Straits Native Corporation on July 18, 2007. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, and the term "State" refers to the State of Alaska. SEC. 4. RATIFICATION OF AGREEMENT. Congress approves, ratifies, and incorporates the Agreement. The terms of the Agreement shall control in case of conflict with any other provision of law. The Secretary is authorized to carry out all actions under the Agreement.
